definition: A tradable unit equal to 1 tonne of CO₂e avoided or removed.
example: A reforestation project issues 100,000 credits after verification.
greenwash_watch: Credits with weak additionality or poor MRV are low‑quality.

definition: Using carbon credits to compensate for emissions elsewhere.
example: A company retires credits to balance residual Scope 1–3 emissions.
greenwash_watch: Offsets used to avoid internal decarbonisation.

definition: Total greenhouse gas emissions of an entity, activity, or product.
example: A firm calculates annual emissions across operations and supply chain.

definition: A common unit that expresses different GHGs as CO₂ based on GWP.
example: Methane reported in CO₂e using GWP100 factors.
greenwash_watch: Mixing GWP20 and GWP100 without clarity.

definition: Metric tonne of CO₂ equivalent (1,000 kg CO₂e).
greenwash_watch: Confusing tonnes (t) with tons or kg.

definition: Gases that trap heat: CO₂, CH₄, N₂O, HFCs, PFCs, SF₆, NF₃.
example: Inventory includes CO₂ and methane from operations.

definition: Heat-trapping impact of a gas over 100 years relative to CO₂.
greenwash_watch: Cherry‑picking lower factors to shrink footprint.

definition: 20‑year GWP highlighting short‑lived climate pollutants.
greenwash_watch: Using whichever GWP yields prettier numbers.

definition: Reference emissions level for measuring reductions.
example: ICE van at 8 L/100 km vs EV electricity use.
greenwash_watch: Inflating baseline activity or fuel to over‑credit.

definition: Evidence project would not occur without credit revenue or is not mandated.
example: Taxi EV rollout only viable with credit cashflows.
greenwash_watch: Crediting already profitable or legally required projects.

definition: Emissions that shift outside project boundary because of the project.
example: Protecting one forest moves logging elsewhere.
greenwash_watch: Ignoring activity shifting to other areas.

definition: Durability of climate benefit; risk of reversal.
example: Forestry projects use buffers to cover fire risks.

definition: Same reduction claimed by more than one entity.
example: Both a company and a country claim the same credits.

definition: Claiming the same renewable MWh in more than one place/instrument.
example: Supplier and buyer both claim one REC.

definition: Permanently removing a credit from circulation so claims are unique.
example: Buyer retires credit serials in a registry.

definition: Database that issues, tracks, and retires credits with unique serials.
example: Verra or Gold Standard registry entry shows serials.

definition: Assigning unique serial numbers to credits for traceability.
example: Batch issued with distinct serial blocks.
greenwash_watch: Recycling serials or poor audit trails.

definition: Year/period when reductions occurred.
greenwash_watch: Mixing vintages to mask weak years.

definition: Defined sources/sinks/activities included in accounting.
example: Use‑phase emissions for EV charging project.
greenwash_watch: Shifting boundaries mid‑analysis to boost results.

definition: Bias estimates downward when uncertainty exists to avoid over‑crediting.
example: Apply conservative grid factors and losses.

definition: Quantified error/variability in data/estimates.
End‑to‑end process to quantify and verify outcomes.
example: Independent verifier checks data against methodology.

definition: Rulebook for baselines, monitoring, boundaries, and calculation.
example: VM0038 defines EV charging crediting rules.

definition: Independent review of project design before implementation.
Independent confirmation of achieved reductions post‑monitoring.
Deep emissions cuts aligned with science plus neutralisation of residuals.
example: Company aligns to SBTi Net‑Zero Standard.
greenwash_watch: Declaring net zero via offsets alone.

definition: Going beyond net zero by removing more GHGs than emitted.
example: Firm removes 10% more than residual footprint.

definition: Balancing emissions with equivalent removals/offsets for a period.
example: Event offsets remaining emissions to be ‘carbon neutral’.

definition: Misleading claims about environmental benefits.
example: Using petrol baseline to inflate EV savings.
greenwash_watch: Any claim not backed by data and audits.

definition: Widely used standards for corporate GHG accounting.
example: Company follows Corporate Standard for inventory.

definition: Direct emissions from owned or controlled sources.
Indirect emissions from purchased electricity, heat, steam, cooling.
greenwash_watch: Reporting only the lower market‑based number.

definition: All other indirect emissions in value chain (up/downstream).
example: Purchased goods, travel, use of sold products.

definition: Documented procedures for data collection, QA/QC, and uncertainty.
example: Meters on chargers, telematics on vehicles.

definition: Processes ensuring data accuracy, completeness, consistency.
example: Monthly checks of meter drift and data gaps.
greenwash_watch: No QA/QC leading to unreliable results.

definition: Statistical approach to select representative data points.
example: Sample odometer readings for a fleet.

definition: Direct measurement of energy or activity.
example: Revenue‑grade meters on DC fast chargers.

definition: Vehicle or asset telemetry used for activity and performance data.
example: GPS and kWh per trip inform reductions.

definition: Rules for storing and making data auditable over time.
Routine verification of instrument accuracy.
Coefficient that converts activity data to emissions.
greenwash_watch: Using outdated factors to inflate benefits.

definition: CO₂e per kWh for a grid region/time.
example: SA grid ~0.9+ kgCO₂/kWh used for EV credits.
greenwash_watch: Relying on national averages that mask hour/location.

definition: Scope 2 method using physical grid mix.
greenwash_watch: Ignoring market instruments and vice versa.

definition: Scope 2 method using contractual instruments (RECs/EACs).
example: Report residual mix and purchased attributes.

definition: Align consumption with renewable generation hourly/daily.
Losses from grid to battery (and auxiliaries).
Fuel cycle + use‑phase boundary for transport.
example: Diesel refining + combustion vs EV electricity.

definition: Total emissions across the lifecycle (cradle‑to‑grave).
greenwash_watch: Counting only use‑phase to look better.

definition: Shared reserve of credits to manage reversal risks.
Assessment of emissions outside boundary due to project.
Pre‑approved baseline values/approaches for a sector/region.
example: A  grid baseline factor for a country.

definition: Level below which errors don’t affect decisions materially.
greenwash_watch: Using materiality to mask systemic bias.

definition: Method of combining measurement errors to total uncertainty.
Global climate treaty adopted in 2015 to limit warming well below 2°C.
greenwash_watch: Assuming voluntary credits equal compliance units.

definition: Paris framework for international cooperation including credit transfers.
Bilateral or club transfers of mitigation outcomes with adjustments.
UN‑supervised crediting mechanism succeeding the CDM.
greenwash_watch: Treating 6.4 as fully live before implementation.

definition: Non‑market approaches: cooperation without trading credits.
Accounting change to prevent double claiming between countries.
example: Host applies CA when credits exported for use abroad.

definition: A country’s climate target and plan under the Paris Agreement.
example: Host country tracks progress toward NDC.

definition: Government letter approving credit use/transfer under A6.
Internationally Transferred Mitigation Outcome under Article 6.2.
Emission reductions under Article 6.4 mechanism.
greenwash_watch: Assuming equivalence to current VCM credits.

definition: EU cap‑and‑trade system for emissions allowances (EUAs).
example: Power and industry surrender EUAs annually.
greenwash_watch: Assuming VCM credits can satisfy ETS duties.

definition: Border levy aligning carbon costs for certain imports into the EU.
example: Steel exporter must report embedded CO₂ and pay CBAM charges.
greenwash_watch: Claiming CBAM can be offset with voluntary credits.

definition: United Kingdom cap‑and‑trade scheme post‑Brexit.
greenwash_watch: Confusing UK ETS with EU ETS allowances.

definition: Statewide compliance market covering power, industry, fuels.
Regional Greenhouse Gas Initiative in US Northeast for power sector.
example: Generators surrender allowances per MWh emissions.
greenwash_watch: Assuming RGGI fungible with other ETS.

definition: National ETS initially for power sector, expanding over time.
example: Coal plants surrender allowances based on benchmarks.
greenwash_watch: Assuming uniform MRV across all provinces.

definition: Republic of Korea cap‑and‑trade program.
Aviation offsetting scheme for growth above 2020 levels.
Phased carbon tax (from 2019) with allowances, escalating price path.
example: Industrial emitters pay tax net of allowances.
greenwash_watch: Equating tax offsets with VCM credits.

definition: Tax‑free allowances reducing payable emissions under SA Carbon Tax.
Government‑set limit on total emissions over a period.
greenwash_watch: Credits used to distract from exceeding budgets.

definition: Coalition aligning on carbon pricing and border rules.
Marketplace where non‑state actors buy credits for voluntary goals.
example: Company buys high‑integrity credits for residuals.
greenwash_watch: Cheap low‑quality credits for big ‘neutral’ claims.

definition: Regulated markets where allowances/offsets satisfy legal duties.
Largest voluntary crediting program and registry (Verified Carbon Standard).
example: Projects issued as VCUs with serials.
greenwash_watch: Assuming all VCUs are high integrity by default.

definition: Program emphasising sustainable development and MRV quality.
example: Household energy and community projects common.
greenwash_watch: Assuming GS label equals perfect quality.

definition: US voluntary program/registry with methodologies across sectors.
greenwash_watch: Confusing ACR credits with compliance units.

definition: North American registry with protocols (e.g., ODS, forestry).
Kyoto‑era UN mechanism issuing CERs; legacy for A6.4.
greenwash_watch: Treating CERs as equivalent to modern high‑integrity units.

definition: Program focused on community‑based land use projects.
Japan’s bilateral mechanism crediting low‑carbon tech abroad.
Sets Core Carbon Principles and labels for programs/methodologies.
greenwash_watch: Assuming CCP label auto‑confers project quality.

definition: Guidance for credible corporate claims using credits.
example: Company attains VCMI Silver/Gold claim after meeting prerequisites.
greenwash_watch: Using VCMI branding without internal reductions.

definition: Alliance promoting best practice for offsets and providers.
Ratings framework by EDF/WRI/Oeko‑Institut to assess credit quality.
Independent project ratings assessing integrity risks.
example: Buyer uses ratings to screen purchases.

definition: Standard for verifying sustainable development outcomes (Verra).
greenwash_watch: Using SD icons without SD VISta evidence.

definition: Immediate delivery trading of credits/allowances.
example: Brokered OTC deal settles this week.

definition: Bilateral trading outside exchanges.
Trading credits/allowances on organised exchanges.
example: EUAs on ICE; some VCM futures listed.

definition: Standardised contracts for delivery at a future date/price.
Custom future delivery agreements (OTC).
example: Pre‑pay for 2026 credits from project under construction.

definition: Right but not obligation to buy/sell credits at set price.
Process by which market finds fair prices via trading.
Ability to transact size without moving price.
example: EUAs are liquid; many VCM credits illiquid.
greenwash_watch: Assuming large blocks can trade instantly.

definition: Mismatch between hedged instrument and exposure.
example: Hedging with index that doesn’t match project type.

definition: Risk the other party defaults on obligations.
example: OTC forward buyer fails to pay on delivery.

definition: Risk project cannot deliver credits on time or at all.
Price differences between older and newer vintages.
Spreading purchases across types/regions to reduce risk.
Using derivatives to reduce price/volume risk.
example: Buy futures to lock in compliance costs.

definition: Documented contributions to UN Sustainable Development Goals.
example: Air quality, jobs, health from EV projects.
greenwash_watch: Claiming SDGs without indicators and monitoring.

definition: Ensuring fair distribution of climate benefits and costs.
greenwash_watch: Benefits captured only by affluent areas.

definition: Equity in project design and revenue sharing.
Contract allocating project revenue among stakeholders.
example: Taxi association gets % of credit revenue.

definition: Rights‑based process to obtain community consent.
Process for stakeholders to raise and resolve issues.
example: Helpdesk and escalation policy in PDD.

definition: Respecting land, culture, and governance of Indigenous Peoples.
Improvements to ecosystems alongside carbon outcomes.
Reductions in air pollution and improved public health.
Ensuring women benefit equally from projects.
example: Jobs and training for women in depots.

definition: Addressing disproportionate burdens on vulnerable communities.
example: Site projects to reduce local pollution.

definition: Credit meeting robust MRV, additionality, and safeguards.
example: EV credits with renewable matching and verified data.

definition: Higher prices for credits with proven co‑benefits and integrity.
example: SDG‑verified credits sell at a premium.

definition: Reducing Emissions from Deforestation and forest Degradation plus conservation and enhancement.
example: Amazon protection project issues REDD+ credits.
greenwash_watch: Leakage and unclear tenure undermine integrity.

definition: Planting trees or revegetating to increase carbon stocks.
Changing forest practices to increase stocks/reduce emissions.
Carbon stored in coastal/marine ecosystems (mangroves, seagrass, saltmarsh).
Rewetting/degrading peatlands to stop oxidation and emissions.
example: Blocking drains to raise water tables.

definition: Avoiding conversion/overgrazing to retain soil carbon.
greenwash_watch: Difficult MRV of soil carbon changes.

definition: Integrating trees into farming systems to store carbon.
example: Shade coffee with trees increases stocks.

definition: Charred biomass added to soils to store carbon long‑term.
example: Biochar from ag residues credited as removals.

definition: Strategic burning to reduce catastrophic fires and emissions.
Benefits people obtain from ecosystems (carbon, water, biodiversity).
Units representing measured biodiversity outcomes.
Monitoring area around project to assess displacement.
Removing CO₂ directly from ambient air via chemical sorbents.
example: DAC plant stores CO₂ in basalt formations.

definition: Generating energy from biomass and capturing/storing CO₂.
example: Biomass CHP with CCS yields removals.

definition: Capturing CO₂ from point sources and storing underground.
greenwash_watch: Used to prolong fossil assets without transition.

definition: Enhanced rock weathering/mineralisation binds CO₂ into carbonates.
Capturing CH₄ from waste and using/flaring to CO₂ reduces impact.
greenwash_watch: Claiming credit without monitoring destruction efficiency.

definition: Credits from reducing energy use relative to baseline.
Credits from renewable generation displacing fossil power (context‑dependent).
greenwash_watch: Crediting in mature grids with no additionality.

definition: Electrification tech replacing fossil heating with efficient systems.
example: Air‑source heat pumps credited where additional.

definition: Hydrogen made via electrolysis with renewable power.
example: Industrial fuel switching from grey to green H₂.

definition: Synthetic fuels made using captured CO₂ and green H₂.
Public/Depot charging delivering metered kWh to EVs.
greenwash_watch: Counting installation rather than electricity delivered.

definition: Optimising charge times for low emissions/cost.
example: Shift to low‑EF hours increases impact.

definition: EVs provide power back to grid, potentially lowering system emissions.
greenwash_watch: Double counting energy and carbon benefits.

definition: Tradable unit representing collection or recycling of plastic waste.
example: Company funds removal of 1 tonne of plastic.
greenwash_watch: No proof of additional recycling capacity.

definition: Credit for recycling electronic waste to avoid pollution/emissions.
Policy requiring producers to manage product end‑of‑life.
Shared responsibility model for managing products’ impacts.
greenwash_watch: Counting regulatory compliance as voluntary impact.

definition: Recovering materials from end‑of‑life batteries to cut embodied emissions.
Reusing EV batteries in stationary storage before recycling.
greenwash_watch: Crediting reuse and recycling for same device.

definition: Turning waste into energy; may reduce methane but emits CO₂.
Aerobic treatment of organics avoids landfill methane.
greenwash_watch: Poor gas capture data at landfills.

definition: Shifting waste from landfill to reuse/recycle/compost.
greenwash_watch: Shifting to low‑value or exported waste streams.

definition: Multiplier reflecting non‑CO₂ climate impacts of aviation.
example: RFI used for true climate impact of flights.
greenwash_watch: Using CO₂‑only to understate aviation impact.

definition: Book‑and‑claim certificates for low‑carbon aviation fuels.
example: Airline purchases SAFc to lower footprint.
greenwash_watch: Counting both fuel user and buyer claims.

definition: Chain‑of‑custody model allowing claims without physical delivery match.
example: Corporate buys certificates for remote impact.

definition: Financial, regulatory, barrier, and common practice tests for additionality.
Two families of policy instruments for emissions mitigation.
example: VCM is baseline‑and‑credit; ETS is cap‑and‑trade.

definition: Reducing credited volumes to address risks/uncertainties.
greenwash_watch: Using minimal discounts despite large risks.

definition: Level below which sources may be excluded from accounting.
Required confidence/precision levels for estimates.
Documentation that allows a third party to reproduce results.
Cross‑checking totals across sources/systems for consistency.
example: Sum of meters equals billed energy.

definition: Movement of credits between registries or tokenised platforms.
Rules defining which projects/credits can be used for a purpose.
Share of issued credits reserved to cover reversal risk.
Formal host approval for credits used toward foreign claims.
Host country letter confirming project participation under Article 6.
greenwash_watch: Operating without LoA and calling credits ITMOs.
